The purpose of this paper is to present results of investigations of the electrical resistance of palladium and palladium-gold alloy (50 wt% Au and Pd) in gaseous hydrogen in the available pressure range at 25 *C. Palladium was chosen because of its large and reproducible changes of the eleetrical resistance obaerved in high-pressure gascous hydrogen |3]. It was interesting to check if the previously oberved [3] inear relationship between the relative clectrical renintance of palladium foils and ganeous hydrogen fugacity exints for higher pressure and if it depends on the contact between hydrogen and the organic liquid. The palladiurn-gold alloy was chosen because of its interesting course of the electrieal resistance at low hydrogen concentrations, namnely its decrease with the inerease of the atomic ratio H:Pd [7].

The scheme of the high-pressure apparatus used is given on Fig. 1. This device is & double piston-cylinder system, working with a double hydraulic press. The first piston-cylinder syutem (I) is s typical Bridgman high-pressure apparatus which is made of high-quality steel. (More details are given in [8]) The gecond system (ll) eonsists of the high-pressure gaseous hydrogen (a). lt is separated from the transmitting liquind (b) by a sealed piston (e). The seal of that piston allows to fil the second system (ll) with pure hydrogen under preasure of 250 to 500 at in a special equipnent outuide of the systenm (I). This procedure is more effective in protecting the steel from the destructive action of gascous hydrogen than that uned previonnly (5]. The system (ll) is exposed to small pressure difference only and therefore its mechanical resistance is of little importance. The sampies investigated, consisting of 10 to 20 um Pd and Pd-Au foils, were placed around an organie glass cylinder $( c )$ avoiding any stressing.
